key_findings.clinical_significance: Essential for early diabetic retinopathy detection
Important for consistent automated analysis across datasets

key_findings.finding: FDR correction reveals more discoveries than Bonferroni
key_findings.clinical_significance: More appropriate statistical approach for exploratory medical imaging research

trade_offs.description: CLAHE offers 1100x faster processing but MSRCR provides superior pathology detection
trade_offs.recommendation: Choose based on clinical workflow: CLAHE for screening, MSRCR for diagnosis

trade_offs.description: CLAHE excels in local contrast enhancement while Retinex methods achieve global uniformity
trade_offs.recommendation: Consider primary diagnostic need: vessel analysis (CLAHE) vs illumination correction (MSR)

clinical_recommendations.rationale: Exceptional speed (~34ms) with adequate quality for initial screening
clinical_recommendations.implementation_note: Can process 1000 images in <1 minute vs 8+ hours for Retinex methods

clinical_recommendations.rationale: Superior microaneurysm detection capability for pathology identification
clinical_recommendations.implementation_note: Computational cost justified by enhanced diagnostic sensitivity

clinical_recommendations.rationale: Best illumination uniformity for consistent preprocessing
clinical_recommendations.implementation_note: Reduces inter-image variability in large-scale studies

statistical_rigor.correction_method: Benjamini-Hochberg FDR (recommended over Bonferroni for exploratory analysis)
statistical_rigor.effect_sizes: Large effect sizes observed (Cohen's d > 0.8) indicating clinically meaningful differences
